subject: Art
title: Color Palettes for Illustration
description: Choosing and using limited color palettes that create cohesive illustrations.

hook.text: A beginner uses 20 colors. A professional uses 5. Limited palettes create cohesion, mood, and impact. The fewer the colors, the more each one matters â€” and the more harmonious the result.

buildup.text: Palette structures: monochromatic (one hue, varied values â€” unified), analogous (neighboring hues â€” harmonious), complementary pair + neutrals (dynamic), triadic (three evenly spaced â€” vibrant). Start with the mood and choose the structure.

discovery.text: The 60-30-10 rule: 60% dominant color (background, large areas), 30% secondary color (supporting elements), 10% accent color (focal points, details). This ratio creates balance with a clear visual hierarchy.

twist.text: Restrict yourself to 3-4 colors and you'll be forced to use value (light/dark) to differentiate elements. This constraint often produces better results than unlimited colors because it creates automatic harmony.

climax.text: Illustrate a scene using only 4 colors (plus black and white). The limitation forces creative problem-solving: can you show night vs day? Foreground vs background? Happy vs sad? All within 4 hues.

punchline.text: A limited palette doesn't limit expression â€” it focuses it. Four well-chosen colors can say more than the entire spectrum.

quiz.question: What is the 60-30-10 rule in color palette design?
options: 60% dominant color, 30% secondary color, 10% accent color for balanced visual hierarchy
60% of the time, use 30 colors with 10 blending modes
Apply color to 60% of the canvas
